questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to AIIMS OPD with complaints of oligomenorrhea for the past six months. She has a history of two previous pregnancies, both of which resulted in miscarriages. She underwent an HSG which is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GU TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salpingitis isthmica nodosa seen on HSG is a classic manifestation of genitourinary tuberculosis (GU TB) , characterized by nodular outpouchings in the fallopian tubes, and can be associated with infertility and menstrual irregularities.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with sudden onset altered semsorium. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pontine hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pontine hemorrhage is a life-threatening condition characterized by sudden onset altered sensorium due to its involvement of the brainstem and vital centers. It is commonly associated with hypertension .

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the images shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Maffucci syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maffucci syndrome is distinguished by the combination of multiple enchondromas and soft-tissue hemangiomas, often seen as phleboliths on imaging.

questions.text: Identify the correct pair:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Putty Kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Putty Kidney is characterized by a non-functioning, shrunken kidney with extensive calcification, often due to chronic renal infections like tuberculosis.

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Left atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left atrium is the posterior-most heart chamber, situated just anterior to the vertebral column and adjacent to the aorta, making it identifiable on axial CT images of the chest.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with cough and dyspnea for 15 days. All are differentials except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) COVID-19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ COVID-19 typically presents with ground-glass opacities rather than miliary nodules, making it atypical in cases of diffuse micronodular patterns in the lungs.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure on the MRI:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PCL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is identified on sagittal MRI images by its posterior insertion on the tibia and thicker appearance compared to the ACL.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with chronic ear discharge, headache, and ear pain. CT revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cerebellar abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebellar abscesses can develop as a complication of chronic ear infections, spreading to the posterior cranial fossa and presenting with symptoms like headache, ear pain, and focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for PTH adenoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tc99-Sestamibi scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Tc99-Sestamibi scan is the preferred imaging modality for localizing parathyroid adenomas, particularly in cases of primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its high sensitivity and ability to differentiate parathyroid from thyroid tissue.
  • ➤ Tc99-Sestamibi scan

questions.text: What is the least useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis of the patient with the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 24-hour pH monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 24-hour pH monitoring is the least useful investigation for diagnosing achalasia , as it primarily assesses acid reflux rather than esophageal motility.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT urography images shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Retrocaval ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retrocaval ureter is a congenital anomaly where the right ureter passes behind the inferior vena cava (IVC), leading to a characteristic "fish-hook" appearance on imaging.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She has a past medical history of hypertension and is a nonsmoker. She reports no significant symptoms except for occasional chest discomfort that she attributes to indigestion. CECT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thymolipoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thymolipoma is a benign anterior mediastinal mass characterized by mixed density due to the presence of both fat and thymic tissue, often detected incidentally on imaging.

questions.text: A patient with a deep-seated brain tumor is scheduled for radiation therapy. The treatment plan includes using a type of radiation that delivers the highest energy dose at the end of its path, minimizing exposure to the surrounding healthy brain tissue. This technique is advantageous for treating the tumor while preserving as much healthy tissue as possible. Which type of radiation achieves this through the Bragg's peak effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Protons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proton therapy utilizes the Bragg peak effect, allowing it to deliver a high dose of radiation precisely at the target site, minimizing exposure to surrounding healthy tissues, making it ideal for treating deep-seated tumors.

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of fluid to be detected by this X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 25 ml

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lateral chest X-ray can detect as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid , making it a more sensitive option for identifying small pleural effusions compared to an upright PA chest X-ray.
  • ➤ 25 ml of pleural fluid

questions.text: Identify the tip of the pacemaker:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The right ventricle (RV) is the typical target location for the tip of a standard pacemaker lead, providing effective pacing for ventricular contraction.

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 0.5 cm solid mass in her gall bladder on USG as shown. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure the patient and follow up

questions.correct_answer: A. Reassure the patient and follow up
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reassure the patient and follow up

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For gallbladder polyps less than 1 cm , conservative management with follow-up imaging is typically appropriate, as the risk of malignancy is low.
  • ➤ gallbladder polyps less than 1 cm
  • ➤ follow-up imaging

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cephalhematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal blood collection confined to a single cranial bone, and it does not cross suture lines. It presents as a localized swelling that resolves gradually over time.
  • ➤ cephalhematoma

questions.text: Identify the marked segment of the liver:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Segment V

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Segment V of the liver is located in the right lobe, below the plane of the right portal vein and adjacent to the gallbladder fossa, making it an important segment to identify in imaging.
  • ➤ Segment V

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl is diagnosed with a febrile urinary tract infection. A voiding cystourethrogram is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's presentation?

options.label: C
options.text: Obstruction due to a renal stone

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of a posterior urethral valve

questions.correct_answer: A. Congenital short intravesical ureter length
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital short intravesical ureter length

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is often caused by a congenital short intravesical ureter length , leading to impaired function of the ureterovesical junction and a higher risk of febrile UTIs in infants.

questions.text: Identify the modality shown here:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CT (Computed Tomography) is the preferred imaging modality for detailed evaluation of the urinary system, often used with contrast to visualize structures like the kidneys, ureters, and bladder in CT urography .
  • ➤ CT (Computed Tomography)
  • ➤ CT urography

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presents to you with jaundice. USG of the liver shows the following abnormality. What is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intra-operative cholangiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For infants with suspected biliary atresia , intra-operative cholangiography is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis, as it provides direct visualization of the biliary tree and guides surgical management.
  • ➤ biliary atresia
  • ➤ intra-operative cholangiography

questions.text: Identify the true statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Left heart border silhouette sign negative

options.label: D
options.text: Location cannot be commented without CT

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Location in Lingula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The silhouette sign on a chest X-ray indicates that a pathology lies in the anatomical region adjacent to the obscured structure. Loss of the left heart border suggests that the pathology is in the lingula of the left upper lobe.
  • ➤ silhouette sign
  • ➤ left heart border
  • ➤ lingula

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to their primary care physician with a complaint of dysphagia. He reports that he experiences a sensation of food getting stuck in his throat when he eats. He also reports some mild chest discomfort with exertion. The patient has a history of Down syndrome and congenital heart disease. A barium swallow is shown here. Which imaging modality should be performed next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Computed tomography angiography (CTA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with dysphagia and suspicion of a vascular anomaly causing extrinsic compression of the esophagus, computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the preferred imaging modality to visualize the vascular structures and their relationship to the esophagus.
  • ➤ computed tomography angiography (CTA)

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the trauma center after a skid injury, with lower abdominal pain and blood at the meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) RGU (Retrograde urethrogram)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with trauma and blood at the urethral meatus , retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is the next best step to evaluate for a possible urethral injury before attempting catheterization or other interventions.
  • ➤ retrograde urethrogram (RGU)

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to respiratory distress. Severe cough and wheezing began an hour ago while the patient was playing at his cousin’s house. The chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Foreign body aspiration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foreign body aspiration should be considered in children with a sudden onset of respiratory distress and unilateral hyperinflation on chest radiographs, especially when the symptoms began during play or after eating.
  • ➤ Foreign body aspiration

questions.text: Identify the correct pair:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MR - AD PKD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (AD PKD) presents with large cysts throughout the kidneys, and MRI is a valuable tool for evaluating the extent of cystic involvement and monitoring disease progression.
  • ➤ Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (AD PKD)
  • ➤ MRI

questions.text: A 35-year-old trumpet blower presents with a neck swelling. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule that can be associated with activities involving high intralaryngeal pressure, such as playing wind instruments, and presents as an air-filled structure on imaging.
  • ➤ laryngocele

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma and is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

options.label: D
options.text: Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inverse square law is a fundamental concept in radiotherapy, stating that the intensity of radiation decreases with the square of the distance from the source, allowing for precise targeting of tumors while minimizing exposure to surrounding tissues.
  • ➤ inverse square law

questions.text: All of the following may be false negative on the image shown below except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) TB (Tuberculosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FDG PET-CT is effective in detecting diseases with high metabolic activity, such as infections and inflammation (e.g., TB ), while certain tumors, including typical carcinoid , mucinous adenocarcinoma , and insulinoma , may show false-negative results due to their lower FDG uptake.
  • ➤ FDG PET-CT
  • ➤ TB
  • ➤ typical carcinoid
  • ➤ mucinous adenocarcinoma
  • ➤ insulinoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with subacute knee pain and swelling. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Baker’s cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Baker’s cyst is a fluid-filled structure in the popliteal fossa that is often associated with knee joint inflammation or internal injury. It presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on MRI, causing posterior knee pain and swelling.
  • ➤ Baker’s cyst

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydatid cysts of the liver present as well-defined, cystic lesions and are caused by Echinococcus granulosus infection. They can be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging studies performed for other reasons.
  • ➤ Hydatid cysts

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department after injuring his right shoulder during a basketball game. He was trying to block a shot when his abducted and externally rotated arm was forced backward by an opposing player. The patient immediately felt excruciating pain and fell to the ground holding his right arm. He has no other medical conditions and has never had a similar injury. On examination, there is gross asymmetry of the right shoulder compared to the left, and the right arm is held in slight abduction and external rotation. Distal pulses are full. Plain film X-ray of the right shoulder is shown below. If left untreated, which of the following is the most likely complication of this patient's injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Shoulder abduction weakness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An anterior shoulder dislocation can lead to injury of the axillary nerve , resulting in weakness in shoulder abduction due to impaired function of the deltoid muscle.
  • ➤ anterior shoulder dislocation
  • ➤ axillary nerve
  • ➤ weakness in shoulder abduction

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with low backache for 20 days. CE-MRI is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pott's spine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pott's spine (spinal tuberculosis) often presents with chronic back pain, vertebral body destruction, and paraspinal abscess formation. It should be considered in patients with insidious onset of symptoms and characteristic MRI findings.
  • ➤ Pott's spine (spinal tuberculosis)

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT enterography.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CT enterography is a non-invasive imaging technique using oral contrast and CT imaging to evaluate the small bowel, particularly useful in diagnosing Crohn's disease and other small intestinal disorders.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Egg on side, TGA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) is associated with the "egg-on-a-string" appearance on chest X-ray due to the narrow mediastinum and the globular heart shape, resulting from abnormal alignment of the great vessels.
  • ➤ Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA)
  • ➤ "egg-on-a-string" appearance

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Right 5th posterior rib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On a chest X-ray, posterior ribs appear more horizontal and arching toward the spine, whereas anterior ribs curve more steeply downward toward the front. Understanding these distinctions helps accurately identify rib levels and positioning.
  • ➤ posterior ribs
  • ➤ anterior ribs

questions.text: All of the following are differentials for the following appearance except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ileal atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "double bubble" sign on an X-ray is a classic indicator of duodenal obstruction, seen in conditions such as duodenal atresia and annular pancreas. Recognizing this appearance helps in differentiating it from other causes of neonatal bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident (RTA). His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, his pulse is 110 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. Which of the following will be the next step in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) eFAST

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemodynamically unstable trauma patients, the initial assessment should prioritize rapid identification of internal bleeding. The eFAST exam is the preferred first-line diagnostic tool in such cases due to its speed, non-invasive nature, and ability to guide immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Doppler USG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient presents with a pulsatile mass in the neck, it is crucial to first evaluate for a vascular etiology using Doppler ultrasound. This investigation helps in safely determining the nature of the mass before considering more invasive procedures.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with backache, morning stiffness, and reddening of the eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by chronic back pain, morning stiffness, and sacroiliac joint involvement. Key features to recognize include the "bamboo spine" appearance on X-rays and association with conditions like anterior uveitis.

questions.text: An 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LUL collapse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Luftsichel sign is a hallmark of left upper lobe (LUL) collapse and appears as a crescent-shaped lucency adjacent to the aortic arch on a chest X-ray. This is often accompanied by a veil-like opacity in the anterior aspect of the left lung.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that has been gradually worsening over the past few weeks. He is actively involved in sports, particularly soccer, and reports increased pain with running and jumping. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osgood-Schlatter disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osgood-Schlatter disease is a common cause of anterior knee pain in adolescents engaged in sports. It results from repetitive stress on the patellar tendon at its insertion point on the tibial tubercle and is diagnosed by clinical history and characteristic X-ray findings, including tibial tuberosity prominence or fragmentation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a history of multiple seizures and developmental delay. On physical examination, you notice facial lesions, hypopigmented macules on the skin, and ungual fibromas. MRI brain is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TSC (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) is a genetic condition characterized by benign tumors in multiple organs, with hallmark findings of seizures, developmental delay, and distinctive skin lesions (such as ash-leaf spots and facial angiofibromas). The brain MRI typically shows cortical and subcortical tubers, contributing to neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. She reports unintentional weight loss over the past few months. On examination, her abdomen is distended, and there is tenderness on deep palpation. A CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superior mesenteric artery syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) Syndrome occurs when the duodenum is compressed between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta, often following significant weight loss. This leads to obstructive symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and progressive weight loss. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with imaging studies showing compression of the duodenum.

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the advantages of different radiation therapy techniques. Brachytherapy is being compared to teletherapy, particularly in the context of its effectiveness and tissue impact. Which of the following statements regarding brachytherapy is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Better than teletherapy for Large & bulky tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Deliver higher dose of radiation to tumor

questions.correct_answer: B. Better than teletherapy for Large & bulky tumor
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Better than teletherapy for large & bulky tumors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brachytherapy is an effective treatment for small, localized tumors and is particularly useful in cancers such as cervical cancer. However, it is less suitable for treating large or bulky tumors, where teletherapy is more effective due to its ability to target a broader area.

questions.text: Identify the bone marked?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Navicular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The navicular bone is located medially in the foot and is an important structure in maintaining the medial longitudinal arch. It articulates with the talus posteriorly and the cuneiform bones anteriorly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe colicky flank pain and hematuria. He has a history of recurrent kidney stones and underwent a procedure for the same two weeks ago. His present X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Steinstrasse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steinstrasse is a complication following procedures like ESWL, where stone fragments line up in the ureter, causing obstruction and symptoms of flank pain and hematuria.
  • ➤ Steinstrasse

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with chronic sinusitis and recurrent respiratory tract infections since childhood. The CXR is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kartagener syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener syndrome is a form of primary ciliary dyskinesia that is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. It results from defective ciliary function, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset breathlessness and sharp pain in his chest after a road traffic accident. His BP is 85/69 mm Hg and HR is 110 bpm. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the next step for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Insert iv cannula and start iv fluids

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ICD insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of traumatic pneumothorax, the primary management involves the insertion of an intercostal chest drain (ICD) to allow the collapsed lung to re-expand. Needle thoracostomy is reserved for tension pneumothorax, while imaging (like eFAST) may assist with diagnosis but should not delay definitive treatment once a pneumothorax is confirmed.
  • ➤ intercostal chest drain (ICD)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with the white arrow:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Concha bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Concha bullosa is the pneumatisation of the middle turbinate, a common variant that can be identified on CT scans. It can contribute to nasal obstruction in some cases but is often asymptomatic.
  • ➤ Concha bullosa
